choices.text: Accelerating the peripheral metabolism of T3
Inhibiting the proteolysis of thyroid-binding globulin
Inhibiting the uptake of iodide by cells in the thyroid
Preventing the addition of iodine to tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was found to have mild hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease. She appears to be in good health otherwise. The decision is made to begin treatment with methimazole. It reduces serum concentration of T3 primarily by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: The thioamides (methimazole and propylthiouracil) act in thyroid cells to prevent conversion of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin to MIT or DIT.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of a cough and runny nose of 1-week duration. While being evaluated, it is discovered that his blood pressure is 230/120 mm Hg. An antihypertensive is immediately administered. Later, he develops lactic acidosis, headache, vertigo, and confusion. Which antihypertensive was given to him?
questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation of confusion, headache, flushed skin and anion gap lactic acidosis is suggestive of cyanide poisoning. The flushed skin and red- colored venous blood seen in patients with cyanide toxicity are a result of impaired oxygen utilization and increased venous oxygen saturation.
  • This patient most likely had hypertensive crisis, may be due to use of alpha agonist use for runny nose, treated with intravenous sodium nitroprusside.
    • Sodium nitroprusside contains cyanide groups and patients who receive prolonged infusions or have kidney disease are at especially high risk of developing cyanide toxicity.
    • Cyanide inhibits the electron transport chain and thereby disables aerobic metabolism, resulting in a switch to anaerobic metabolism that leads to elevated lactate levels and anion gap acidosis. Treatment of cyanide toxicity consists of administration of oxygen, hydroxycobalamin, and sodium thiosulfate.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman is given a prescription of fluconazole to be taken daily (q 12 h) for 3 days. The half-life is 12 h. How long will it take for the medication to reach 90% of its final steady state level?
questions.solution:
To calculate the time it takes for a medication to reach 90% of its final steady state, you can use the formula (3.3) * (t1/2).

Given that the half-life (t1/2) of fluconazole is 12 hours:

Time to Reach 90% of Steady State = (3.3) * (12 hours) = 39.6 hours

So, it will take approximately 39.6 hours for the medication to reach 90% of its final steady-state level. Among the given options, the closest one is:

C) 40 hours

This option is the most accurate representation of the calculated time of approximately 39.6 hours.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man has not urinated after the hernioplasty under spinal anesthesia since 2 days. He reports that the Examination shows a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. He is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects of his treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative or postpartum urinary retention.

Bethanechol is a direct parasympathomimetic that binds to muscarinic receptors, increasing detrusor muscle tone to cause contractions that initiate urination. Although sweat glands are primarily innervated by the sympathetic nervous system, they have muscarinic receptors and are therefore activated by acetylcholine, unlike all other sympathetic pathways. Due to the cholinergic activity of bethanechol, diaphoresis is the most likely adverse effect in this patient.

Side effects of parasympathomimetic drugs are

questions.text: A 27-year old man is suspected of antimuscarinic drug overdose. Probable signs of overdose include which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Tachycardia is a characteristic atropine overdose effect. Bradycardia is sometimes observed after small doses. None of the other choices are typical of atropine.

ATROPINE ACTION

questions.text: Which of the following drugs may inhibit the hepatic microsomal P450 responsible for warfarin metabolism?
questions.solution: Amiodarone is an important anti-arrhythmic drug and has a well-documented ability to inhibit the hepatic metabolism of many drugs.

choices.text: Free radical creation within bacterial cells
Inhibition of peptide translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit

questions.text: A 78-year-old man presents with headache and nonproductive cough for 5 days. Results of cold agglutinin titer testing show a 4-fold elevation above normal. CXR shows diffuse, patchy infiltrates bilaterally. Treatment with an antibiotic acts by?
questions.solution:
• As per given clinical scenario this man has Mycoplasma pneumonia, which typically manifests with insidious onset and causes headaches and a nonproductive cough with diffuse, patchy infiltrates on chest x-ray. Erythrocyte agglutination is seen as a result of high titers of IgM cold agglutinins.
  • Macrolides such as erythromycin and azithromycin are often used to treat Mycoplasma pneumonia. These antibiotics inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit. Doxycycline (which inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S subunit) and fluoroquinolones (which inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerases) are also effective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • Option A. Nitroimidazoles create free radicals within bacteria cells, which leads to DNA strand breaks, used to treat infections with anaerobic bacteria. They are not used to treat Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • Sulfonamides inhibit bacterial synthesis of folic acid by DHPS. Sulfamethoxazole is used in combination with trimethoprim (TMP-SMX) to treat Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (In immunocompromised). Sulfonamides are not indicated for Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Rifamycins inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, used to treat mycobacterial It is not used to treat Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: 54-year-old man was comes with review of his home glucose measurements shows that his PP2BS = 320 mg/dL. His current treatment regimen includes a long-acting subcutaneous insulin injection once a day. Which of the following types of insulin would be most appropriate to administer before each meal?
questions.solution:
• Given scenario of increased PP2BS even after daily long acting insulin needs administration of nutritional insulin before meal. For that monomeric insulins (eg, lispro, aspart, and glulisine) can significantly improved postprandial insulin therapy. Their onset of action is under 15 minutes and peaks at 60 minutes, a pattern that closely mimics the endogenous postprandial insulin response of normal individuals.
  • Option A : While, the peak effect of regular insulin occurs after the postprandial peak in blood glucose concentration.This mismatch between the insulin and glucose peaks generally leads to inadequate control of glucose following meals.
  • Option B & D are basal insulin, while patient is already on basal insulin, 2nd basal dose in unwarranted.
    • BBR = Basal-bolus insulin regimen = Basal insulin: administer as long-acting insulin (e.g., glargine) at bedtime. Nutritional insulin: administer as rapid-acting insulin (e.g., lispro) in equally divided doses before meals
    • SSR = Sliding scale insulin regimen = Administer as short-acting insulin before each meal and at bedtime as per scale.
    • BOT = Basal supported oral therapy = long-acting insulin injection (e.g., glargine) before bedtime combined with an oral antidiabetic drug regimen

choices.text: Decreased channel opening in enteric nerves

questions.text: A laboratory study of new H2 blockers is planned. Which of the following will result from blockade of H2 receptors?
questions.solution: H2 receptors are Gs-protein-coupled receptors, like β adrenoceptors. Blockade of this system will cause a decrease in cAMP in several tissues.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes with nonbloody diarrhoea and right lower quadrant pain. Physical examination shows a palpable right lower quadrant mass and tenderness. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of Crohn disease, an idiopathic inflammatory process, which can affect any portion of the alimentary tract ("from mouth to anus"). This condition is often characterized by intermittent bouts of low-grade fever, diarrhoea, malaise, and weight loss, as well as focal tenderness and a palpable, tender mass in the lower abdomen. There is evidence of ulceration, stricturing, and fistulas of the small intestine and colon.
  • Nonpharmacologic therapy can be efficacious in some cases, but more severe cases may require corticosteroids such as prednisone. Corticosteroids dramatically suppress the clinical signs and symptoms. Patients may require surgical resection of affected bowel segments. Prednisone is the drug of choice for acute "flare-ups."
    1. Dicyclomine is an oral antispasmodic indicated for the treatment of functional irritable bowel syndrome. This agent blocks muscarinic receptors, relaxes smooth muscles in the intestinal tract, and inhibits bradykinin-induced spasms and histamine-induced spasms of the intestinal tract.
    2. Hydrocortisone suppositories are indicated for the treatment of distal ulcerative colitis, not Crohn disease.
    3. Mesalamine is a 5-aminosalicylic acid derivative indicated for the maintenance of remission of ulcerative colitis.

choices.text: Agonist of u opiate receptors of the gastrointestinal tract
Catalyses the hydrolysis of fats to monoacylglycerols, glycerol, and fatty acids
Decreases cholesterol synthesis, secretion, and absorption

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to you because of pain in her right upper abdomen, especially after eating fatty foods, such as potato salad. Her temperature is 100.0 F. Physical examination shows an intense but dull right upper quadrant tenderness as well as inspiratory arrest on deep palpation of the right upper quadrant during deep inspiration. You and the patient determine that medical management would be the best initial option since the patient does not want to undergo a surgical procedure. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the agent that can be used to treat the patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient has symptomatic cholelithiasis. Biliary pain is characterized by infrequent episodes of steady severe dull pain in the epigastrium or right upper quadrant with radiation to the right scapula. A positive Murphy sign(inspiratory arrest on deep palpation of the right upper quadrant during deep inspiration) is also highly suggestive of cholecystitis. Tachycardia and diaphoresis may be present as a consequence of pain and should resolve with appropriate pain management. However, fever, persistent tachycardia, hypotension, or jaundice should warrant a search for complications of cholelithiasis, including cholecystitis, cholangitis, or pancreatitis.
  • The diagnosis is generally confirmed with ultrasound. Ursodeoxycholic acid, is a secondary bile acid, which is a metabolic byproduct of intestinal bacteria. The exact mechanism of this drugs anticholelithic action is not completely understood. However, it is believed that the drug is concentrated in bile and decreases biliary cholesterol by suppressing hepatic synthesis and secretion of cholesterol as well as inhibiting its intestinal absorption. Thus, the decreased cholesterol saturation causes the gradual solubilisation of cholesterol from gallstones, resulting in their eventual dissolution. When used alone, it may take months to years to be fully effective, and it may not produce a full therapeutic response in all patients. It can be combined with ultrasonic lithotripsy to dissolve gallstone fragments. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy may also be used in patients who are surgical candidates.
  • Pancrelipase is a pancreatic lipase preparation that catalyzes the hydrolysis of fats to monoacylglycerols, glycerol, and fatty acids. This agent is used for the treatment of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

questions.text: Which drug stimulates chloride secretion into the gut lumen and is used for irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution: • Linaclotide is approved for the treatment of chronic constipation and IBS with predominant constipation. Linaclotide activates guanylyl cyclase-C on the luminal intestinal epithelial surface, which leads to activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) leading to increased chloride-rich secretion and acceleration of intestinal transit.

questions.text: A 56-year-old presents with fluid retention and edema. With which of the following drugs is this patient most likely being treated?
questions.solution:
• Imatinib is a protein-tyrosine kinase inhibitor that inhibits the bcl-abr tyrosine kinase, which is the constitutive abnormal tyrosine kinase produced by the Philadelphia chromosome in patients with CML. Imatinib is associated with the development of fluid retention, including pleural effusion, ascites, pulmonary edema, and rapid weight gain.
  • Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used to treat breast cancer. It is associated with hot flashes, thromboembolism, osteoporosis, and bone fractures.
  • Bleomycin is an intercalating agent that complexes iron-forming reactive oxygen species and induces DNA strand breaks. It is used to treat squamous cell carcinoma, both Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma as well as testicular carcinoma. This agent is commonly associated with the development of pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department, where her temperature is 99.1°F, pulse is 182/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. An ECG shows ventricular tachycardia. She was diagnosed with alcoholic liver cirrhosis 2 years ago. Examination shows a protruding, distended abdomen that is dull to percussion with a positive fluid wave. Which of the following treatments is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?

Initial laboratory studies show:
questions.solution:
• This patient received medical therapy for ascites (indicated by her clinical findings and history of cirrhosis). Furosemide was likely prescribed to this patient to treat her ascites. If administered in excess, furosemide can lead to a profound diuresis with water and electrolyte depletion, resulting in hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hyponatremia, and ultimately the acute kidney injury and metabolic alkalosis as seen in this patient.
  • Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia can cause life-threatening arrhythmias, such as the ventricular tachycardia suffered by this patient. In addition to correcting this patient's electrolyte levels, management would also include prompt rehydration with intravenous fluids.The drug responsible for her laboratory findings can also cause hyperglycemia and ototoxicity.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman consumed a drug that inhibits Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule in excess. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?
questions.solution:
• Inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics, which are used to treat hypertension, a common comorbidity in elderly patients.
  • Inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early DCT can cause hyponatremia due to increased Na+ excretion. Inhibition of Na+ reabsorption by the early DCT also increases Na+ delivery to the late DCT and early collecting tubule, which can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis due to increased K+ and H+ secretion in exchange for luminal Na+ reabsorption. It also causeshypercalcemia due in part to increased Ca2+ reabsorption at the proximal tubule as a result of increased extracellular fluid reabsorption in this segment.

questions.text: A 31-year-old Woman comes to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever, night sweats, and productive cough. He has also had a 4-kg weight loss. Chest-x ray reveals a cavitary lesion on the right. Sputum culture is obtained. When exposed to drug A, isolates of the pathogen growing in culture quickly become less resistant to decoloration with an acid-alcohol agent and stop proliferating. Which of the following is drug A most likely to be?
questions.solution:
• Isoniazid is an antimicrobial agent that is active only against mycobacteria. Its specificity is derived from its inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Mycolic acids form long branched-chain fatty acids in the outer portion of the mycobacterial peptidoglycan cell wall; they are essential for proper cell wall structure and virulence factor synthesis (eg, sulfatides, wax D, cord factor). If mycobacteria are unable to synthesize mycolic acids, they cannot create proper cell walls or divide to form new cells.
  • Mycolic acids in the cell wall cause mycobacteria to be acid-fast as they retain the carbolfuchsin dye and resist decoloration by an acid-alcohol decolorizing agent.

questions.text: A new born child is admitted into NICU for the phototherapy for neonatal jaundice. He develops fever on 4th day. So, blood culture investigation is done. Blood culture is positive for HSV-1 viral infection. Paediatrician wants to start intravenous acyclovir for treatment. What is the correct dose of acyclovir every 8 hrly for treatment of neonatal HSV infection?
Match the following for positive chronotropic and inotropic effects on heart by Methylxanthines.
questions.solution:
• The methylxanthines have positive chronotropic and inotropic effects.
  • At low concentrations, these effects appear to result from inhibition of presynaptic adenosine receptors in sympathetic nerves increasing catecholamine release at nerve endings.
  • The higher concentrations (> 10 μmol/L, 2 mg/L) associated with inhibition of phosphodiesterase and increases in cAMP may result in increased influx of calcium.
  • At much higher concentrations (> 100 μmol/L), sequestration of calcium by the sarcoplasmic reticulum is impaired.

questions.text: Which is the reference local anaesthetic agent against which all agents are compared?
questions.solution: • Aside from the issue of a high incidence of TNS with spinal administration, lidocaine has had an excellent record as an intermediate duration anaesthetic, and remains the reference standard against which most anaesthetics are compared.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. He states that the pain is worse after eating a fatty meal. His temperature is 102.5 F. Physical examination shows tenderness of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen with guarding. His white blood cell count is 14,500 cells/pL. Ultrasonography shows pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall thickening, abdominal pain when the ultrasound probe is over the gallbladder, and gallstones. Surgery is planned and treatment with an antibiotic regimen is begun. Which of the following pharmacotherapy is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Acute cholecystitis is characterized by acute gallbladder inflammation and is one of the primary complications of cholelithiasis or gallstones. This condition is generally caused by a complete cystic duct obstruction that leads to inflammation and often infection within the gallbladder wall. Diagnosis is made with ultrasound or a hepatobiliary (HIDA) scan.
  • Fever, RUQ tenderness or pain, and sonographic Murphy's sign also point to this diagnosis. Because the infection can be caused by anaerobic, gram-negative or select gram- positive infections, acute cholecystitis treatment is generally started with a third-generation cephalosporin, such as cefotaxime or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole. Other treatments include piperacillin/tazobactam, ampicillin/sulbactam, and meropenem.
  • The cephalosporins are a group of bactericidal antibiotics with broad gram-negative and gram-positive coverage; their anaerobic coverage varies. These agents are inhibitors of bacterial cell wall synthesis. With the addition of metronidazole, there will be adequate anaerobic coverage as well.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the ED, says it feels like "my heart is racing", along with palpitation. Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg and pulse is 164/min. ECG is shown below. Treatment is initiated with a medication, leads to resolution of the symptom but is accompanied by short-lived flushing, burning in the chest, and shortness of breath. Which of the following medications was used to treat this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario of palpitation and given ECG (Typically narrow QRS complexes, Regular rhythm and P wave is typically not visible), consistent with paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the name implies, PSVT comes on suddenly and the focus of automaticity lies above the ventricles (i.e.; atria or atrioventricular node). due to development of a reentrant circuit, the tachyarrhythmia may be terminated by the administration of adenosine.

Adenosine, slows conduction in the atrioventricular node, by hyperpolarizing the tissue (through increased IK) and by reducing calcium current. Adenosine is extremely effective in abolishing AV nodal arrhythmias like PSVT. It's effects are rapid-onset and short-lived (half-life < 10s). The most frequent adverse effects associated with adenosine are flushing, chest burning (due to bronchospasm), hypotension, and high-grade atrioventricular block.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is on stable dose of Carbamazepine. Which of the following drug if prescribe, physician needs to decrease the dose of Carbamazepine ?
questions.solution:
• Carbamazepine is metabolized mainly by cytochrome P450 (CYP) 3A4 to the active carbamazepine 10,11-epoxide, which is further metabolized to the trans-diol by epoxide hydrolase. Therefore, the potential exists for interaction between carbamazepine and any agent that inhibits CYP3A4 and/or epoxide hydrolase.
  • Agents that are CYP3A4 inhibitors that have been expected, to increase plasma levels of Carbamazepine. Thus, if a patient has been titrated to a stable dosage of Carbamazepine and then begins a course of treatment with one of these CYP3A4, it is reasonable to expect that a dose reduction for Carbamazepine may be necessary.
  • Agents that are CYP inducers that have been expected, to decrease plasma levels of Carbamazepine. Thus, if a patient has been titrated to a stable dosage on Carbamazepine, and then begins a course of treatment with one of these CYP3A4 inducers, it is reasonable to expect that a dose increase for Carbamazepine may be necessary.

choices.text: Decreased activity of myosin light-chain kinase
Increased activity of protein kinase C
Increased activity of protein kinase A

questions.text: An 85-year-old man develops bilateral pedal cyanosis and beginning necrosis of the toes 5 days after admission to the ICU for CAP and severe hypotension. The patient has received empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors. All extremities are cold to touch. Which of the following intracellular changes is most likely to occur in vascular smooth muscle as a result of this drug?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario of bilateral necrosis of the toes and coldness of all extremities with history of CAP suggest a septic shock. The persistent vasoplegia associated with septic shock frequently requires prolonged treatment with vasopressors to maintain a mean arterial blood pressure > 65 mm Hg.

Norepinephrine is a vasopressor that preferentially agonises alpha-1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. Prolonged alpha receptor agonism can cause distal arterioles and their branches (especially cutaneous branches) to constrict to the point of causing distal ischemia and consequent necrosis. This phenomenon is most commonly observed in the fingertips and distal toes and manifests with symmetrical discoloration and coldness.


Alpha-1 agonists (e.g., phenylephrine, norepinephrine, midodrine) are used to treat hypotension because increased protein kinase C activity through Gq GPCR patheway -> increases the concentration of intracellular calcium in vascular smooth muscle, which increases vascular smooth muscle contraction.


Option D : Protein kinase A (PKA) is involved in the Gs and Gi GPCR pathways. Activation of Gs protein ultimately leads to activation of protein kinase A. However, NE through alpha-1 receptors acts by Gq GPCR pathway.


Option A : Decreased myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK) activity in vascular smooth muscle would cause vasodilation, a deleterious effect in this patient with a septic shock. MLCK activity in muscle tissue is decreased by 3 mechanisms:

  • Closing L-type voltage-gated calcium channels through membrane repolarisation;
  • Decreasing intracellular calcium concentration through inhibtion of a Gq protein-receptor coupled receptor (While NE acts through alpha-1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle which increases intracellular calcium); and
  • Increasing the activity of protein kinase A through stimulation of Gs protein-coupled receptors.

Option C : Guanylate cyclase activity is increased in vascular smooth muscle by stimulation of ANP or BNP receptors and by drugs that increase nitric oxide concentration (nitrate drugs). Increased guanylate cyclase activity increases cGMP synthesis, which in turn activates myosin-light-chain phosphatase and causes smooth muscle relaxation. Nitroprusside is used to treat hypertensive crisis via this mechanism.

questions.text: Action of drugs 'X' and 'Y' on heart rate with/without pre-treatment shown below in table. Find out drug X and Y respectively
questions.solution:
Drug X causes slowing of the heart rate, but this is converted into tachycardia by hexamethonium and atropine, demonstrating that when it occurs, the bradycardia is caused by reflex vagal discharge. Phenoxybenzamine also reverses the bradycardia to tachycardia, suggesting that α receptors are needed to induce the reflex bradycardia and that also has direct β-agonist actions. So drug X = Norepinephrine

Drug Y causes tachycardia that is not significantly influenced by any of the blockers; therefore, drug Y must have a direct β-agonist effect on the heart. So drug Y = Isoproterenol.

questions.text: 25-year-old woman with a history of resistant depression is found unconscious after ingesting an unknown quantity of amitriptyline. Two hours after arrival, she dies, despite appropriate lifesaving measures. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
• Patients that overdose on tricyclic antidepressants (TADs) experience dangerous and often lethal These arrhythmias may produce hypotension, shock, and death.
  • Thus, monitoring for the cardiac consequences of these drugs is paramount in treating tricyclic overdoses.
  • Tricyclics can lead to the development of QT prolongation, cardiac arrhythmias, AV block, and bundle branch block. Tricyclics act by directly blocking the fast Na channels in cardiac myocytes.
  • The side effects of TADs can result in the 3 C's.cardiotoxicity, convulsions, and coma. Less serious but common side effects of the tricyclics include dry mouth, urinary retention, blurred vision, drowsiness and constipation.
  • Supportive management of toxicity may include endotracheal intubation, hyperventilation (use is controversial but helps produce respiratory alkalosis), treatment with IV sodium bicarbonate, which can treat ventricular arrhythmias that are associated with tricyclic antidepressants.
  • Sodium bicarbonate acts by alkalinizing the serum to oppose the arrhythmia induced by the tricyclics and by directly providing Na+ for the fast channels. Lidocaine has also been used for the treatment of the cardiac arrhythmias. The treatment of choice for prolonged or recurrent seizures in TA toxicity is a benzodiazepine.
  • Due to their overall toxicity, the TCAs have largely been supplanted by the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of major depressive disorder. However, TCAs are still used for treatment resistant major depressive disorder as well as fibromyalgia, other pain syndromes, enuresis and obsessive compulsive disorder.
  • When tricyclics are prescribed, they are often prescribed in smaller amounts than the typical prescription.

questions.text: The addition of carbidopa in patient on levodopa is most likely to decrease the risk of which of the following potential adverse drug effects?
questions.solution:
• Following administration, L-DOPA is absorbed into the systemic circulation where it is partially converted to dopamine by the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase.
  • The remaining L-DOPA is then transported across the blood-brain barrier and enters the central nervous system to produce the desired effects.
  • Carbidopa reduces the peripheral (systemic) conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, thereby mitigating the peripheral sides effects, including orthostatic hypotension, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Option A- Resting tremor is reduced by L-DOPA therapy. The addition of carbidopa is likely to further reduce the incidence of resting tremor because a combination of these drugs would increase the amount of centrally available dopamine. However, resting tremor is a feature of Parkinson disease and not an adverse effect of L-DOPA therapy.
  • Option B- Dyskinesia is a central nervous system side effect of L-DOPA that typically occurs with long-term therapy. By decreasing the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, carbidopa increases the fraction of the administered drug that crosses the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, symptoms of dyskinesia would be expected to increase rather than decrease.
  • Option D- Hallucinations are a central side effect of L-DOPA therapy and they correlate to the concentration of dopamine in the central nervous system. By decreasing the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, carbidopa increases the fraction of the administered drug that crosses the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, visual hallucinations would be expected to increase rather than decrease.

questions.text: Match the following

A 34-year-old woman with hepatitis B virus develops fulminant hepatitis. A liver transplant is successfully performed, and treatment is begun with an immunosuppressant. You recommend avoiding consumption of grapefruit and grapefruit juice when taking this drug. Which of the following is the most likely immunosuppressant administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cyclosporine is indicated for the prevention of renal, heart, and liver transplant rejection and the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis; it may be effective in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and granulomatosis with polyanglitis (Wegener's).
  • Calcineurin normally stimulates transcription factors that lead to increased production of interleukin 2 and related cytokines. Thus, cyclosporine decreases production of IL-2.
  • Cyclosporine has many drug interactions because it is largely metabolized by the CYP3A enzyme system, compounds that alter the activity of this enzyme also affect cyclosporine levels. Grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A, resulting in increased blood concentrations of cyclosporine.
  • Common adverse effects seen with cyclosporine include elevated BUN, hypertension, tremor, infection, and renal impairment. Serious reactions include severe hypertension, severe hyperkalemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, neutropenia, immunosuppression, nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, seizures, and opportunistic infections.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus has HbA1c of 8.5%. Consultant prescribes a drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyses carbohydrate bonds. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
• The drug inhibits alpha-glucosidase, Miglitol, prevents the hydrolysis of polysaccharides to monosaccharides.
  • Since polysaccharides are not absorbed as easily as monosaccharides, alpha-glucosidase therapy results in a slower rise in postprandial blood glucose concentrations.
  • Adverse effects of alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are caused by impaired absorption and include flatulence, diarrhoea, and early satiety.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and tachycardia. A spiral CT scan of the chest shows a pulmonary embolism. Treatment with a medication that causes an almost immediate inactivation of factor lla is begun. Which of the following laboratory studies will most likely be used to monitor the effect of the drug administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Heparin, an anticoagulant that accelerates the activity of antithrombin Ill (ATIll), thereby inactivating thrombin (factor Ila). More specifically, heparin binds reversibly to ATIll and causes an almost instantaneous inactivation of factors lla and Xa.
  • The heparin-ATIll complex can also inactivate factors IX, XI, XIl and plasmin. Heparin prevents progression of existing clots by inhibiting further clotting and the lysis of existing clots relies on endogenous thrombolytics.
  • Heparin is often administered to individuals diagnosed with acute embolism or thrombosis by continuous IV infusion at a rate sufficient to raise the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) to 5-2 times the control value.
  • The aPT measures the intrinsic system and common pathway, which is affected by factors I (fibrinogen), I (prothrombin), V, VIN, IX, X, XI, and XII.
  • In other words, the anticoagulant effect of heparin should be continually monitored to ensure that the patient's aPTT does not 5 to 2 times the control value.
  • If the control aPTT value is exceeded, the risk for internal bleeding can increase The clotting cascade and actions of heparin and warfarin is shown below.
